channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Live Updates: Putin Stokes Anti-American Sentiment as Ukraine Steps Closer to E.U.
item.description: The Russian leader accused the U.S. of treating its allies as colonies while declaring itself “the messenger of the Lord on Earth.” The European Commission recommended that Ukraine be granted E.U. candidate status, the first step in a long process. The prime minister of Britain made another surprise visit to Kyiv.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times

item.title: Russians Breached This City, Not With Troops, but Propaganda
item.description: As they batter towns and cities in Ukraine with artillery, the Russians are also bombarding them with messaging aimed at eroding Ukrainians’ trust in their military and their government.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Natalia Yermak and Tyler Hicks

item.title: Colombia Will Soon Have Its First Black Female Vice President. Will It Be Her?
item.description: A few months ago, Marelen Castillo was a top director of a Catholic university. Now, she is one of two Afro-Colombian women who could become the country’s next second in command.
item.dc:creator: Genevieve Glatsky
item.media:credit: Federico Rios for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dr. Castillo has kept her message centered on improving public education and increasing economic opportunities, particularly for women.

item.title: Extradition Order for Julian Assange Approved by Britain
item.description: Priti Patel, Britain’s home secretary, approved the order. But Mr. Assange, the WikiLeaks founder who faces charges in the U.S. under the Espionage Act, will appeal.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:credit: Victoria Jones/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.media:description: An image of Julian Assange was projected in London in April to mark three years since his arrest and detention in the Belmarsh prison.

item.title: India’s Military Recruitment Plan Fuels Anger and Protest
item.description: Young people seeking job security in a long-term military career saw the announcement as another blow to their dreams amid rising unemployment.
item.dc:creator: Karan Deep Singh and Hari Kumar
item.media:description: Indian paramilitary officers detaining a protester in New Delhi on Friday. A change in government policy on military recruiting and retention prompted demonstrations in several parts of the country.

item.title: Chie Hayakawa Imagines a Japan Where the Elderly Volunteer to Die
item.description: The premise for Chie Hayakawa’s film, “Plan 75,” is shocking: a government push to euthanize the elderly. In a rapidly aging society, some also wonder: Is the movie prescient?
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich
item.media:credit: Noriko Hayashi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Chie Hayakawa in Tokyo. Her new film “Plan 75” takes on one of the biggest elephants in the room in Japan: the challenges of dealing with the world’s oldest society.

item.title: Paolo Macchiarini, Star Surgeon, Loses Court Ruling in Sweden
item.description: Dr. Paolo Macchiarini became a star by creating a “bioartificial” windpipe. But it did not work, and a court in Sweden has found him criminally liable for the harm inflicted on a patient.
item.dc:creator: Euan Ward and Christina Anderson

item.title: China Launches Third Aircraft Carrier in Major Milestone for Xi Jinping
item.description: The vessel, named Fujian after the Chinese province that sits across from Taiwan, is China’s most modern.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Stevenson
item.media:description: The launch ceremony for China’s third aircraft carrier, Fujian, took place on Friday at a dry dock in Shanghai.

item.title: She Spoke Out Against Vietnam’s Plans for Coal. Then She Was Arrested.
item.description: The prosecution of Vietnam’s most prominent environmental activist, as well as others, has cast doubt on the country’s commitment to cut coal.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee
item.media:description: Nguy Thi Khanh, executive director of the environmental group GreenID, at the organization’s Hanoi headquarters in 2020.

item.title: Greek Court Rejects Effort to Toughen Punishment After Killing of an American
item.description: Bakari Henderson, a college graduate from Texas, was beaten to death in a resort area in July 2017. The court on Friday upheld the original convictions.
item.dc:creator: Niki Kitsantonis
item.media:description: Jill and Phil Henderson, front, the parents of Bakari Henderson, outside the courthouse in Patras, Greece, in November 2018, when the original verdict was handed down.

item.title: Fuel-Starved and Stuck in Crisis, Sri Lanka Orders Work from Home
item.description: The decree applies to employees of the state and education sectors, and was aimed at reducing the rush to public transport in the nation of 21 million.
item.dc:creator: Skandha Gunasekara and Mujib Mashal
item.media:description: A line for fuel in Colombo on Friday.

item.title: BTS Ponders Its Future, and South Korea’s Economy Warily Takes Note
item.description: The band’s label saw its stock price plunge, and the possibility that the K-pop group won’t tour as pandemic restrictions ease threatens to reverberate through South Korea’s economy.
item.dc:creator: Jin Yu Young
item.media:description: BTS performing during the Grammy Awards in Las Vegas in April.

item.title: In Ukraine, Some Ethnic Hungarians Feel Ambivalence About the War
item.description: After Moscow’s invasion, some Ukrainians worry that divided loyalties within the country’s small ethnic Hungarian minority might make it susceptible to pro-Russia propaganda from Hungary.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon and Diego Ibarra Sanchez
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: In Mezogecse, in the Zakarpattia Region, the Hungarian community celebrated the National Day of Cohesion, marking the anniversary of the Treaty of Trianon, earlier this month.

item.title: Congo Closes Its Rwanda Border After Soldier Is Killed
item.description: The incident comes as tensions between the two countries have escalated in recent weeks, threatening to destabilize an already volatile, mineral-rich region.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.media:description: The border crossing between Rwanda and the Democratic Republic of Congo in Goma was closed Friday after a Congolese soldier was killed by a Rwandan police officer.

item.title: British Journalist Dom Phillips’s Remains Identified, Brazil’s Police Say
item.description: The remains of a second person, believed to be Bruno Pereira, who disappeared with Mr. Phillips in the Amazon on June 5, were still being analyzed.
item.dc:creator: Reuters
item.media:description: The veteran foreign correspondent Dom Phillips, seen here in Brazil in 2019, disappeared in the Amazon while working on a book.

item.title: Toronto Blue Jays’ Manager By Day, Salsa Musician By Night
item.description: Growing up in Puerto Rico, Montoyo learned to play percussion and salsa music.
item.dc:creator: James Wagner
item.media:credit: Brendan George Ko for The New York Times
item.media:description: Charlie Montoyo, the manager of the Toronto Blue Jays, making music.

item.title: A Defiant Putin Says Russia Will Flourish Without the West
item.description: In a speech at an economic forum, he called the U.S. a fading power and said sanctions on Russia, not the Ukraine war, are hurting Western economies.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski, Andrew E. Kramer and Michael Levenson
item.media:description: A large screen showing President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia at the St. Petersburg International Economic Forum on Friday.

item.title: Foreign Fighters in Ukraine Face Perils if Captured
item.description: Thousands of foreign fighters have gone to fight for Ukraine, but not all join its International Legion. Russia has maintained that some of foreign fighters it has captured are mercenaries.
item.dc:creator: Jane Arraf and James C. McKinley Jr.
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Foreign fighters in Ukraine, whether they have joined the country’s International Legion or one of the loosely organized outfits around the country, face the prospect of hostile treatment if captured by Russian forces, in addition to the obvious perils faced by Ukrainian nationals who have joined the fight.

item.title: Internal challenges like corruption pose challenges in Ukraine’s bid to join the E.U.
item.description: The rules for joining the European Union require candidate nations crack down on corruption, a problem that Ukraine has struggled to address, including since President Volodymyr Zelensky took office.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: Although Ukraine has won over many Europeans in its campaign for E.U. membership, it might face a long road of internal reform before joining the bloc.

item.title: Russian Spy Stopped From Infiltrating the ICC, Dutch Intelligence Says
item.description: Sergey Vladimirovich Cherkasov spent years building an identity as a Brazilian citizen, polishing a résumé that got him an internship at the court, officials say.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: The International Criminal Court in The Hague

item.title: Here is what to know about the Covid vaccine for infants and toddlers.
item.dc:creator: Melinda Wenner Moyer
item.media:credit: Illustration by Matt Chase; Photograph By Getty Images

item.title: Boris Johnson Pays a Second Surprise Visit to Kyiv
item.description: Boris Johnson promised new military aid that would train up to 10,000 Ukrainian soldiers every 120 days.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:credit: Ukrainian Presidential Press Service, via AFP
item.media:description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain, left, paid a surprise visit to President Volodymyr Zelensky in Kyiv, Ukraine, on Friday.

item.title: Egypt, America’s Middle Eastern ally, maintains warm relations with Putin.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee
item.media:description: President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi of Egypt has tried to balance his country’s relationship with both Russia and the United States, from which it has received billions of dollars in aid.

item.title: Meet the Peecyclers. Their Idea to Help Farmers Is No. 1.
item.description: A shortage of chemical fertilizer, worsened by the war in Ukraine, has growers desperate. It just so happens that human urine has the very nutrients that crops need.
item.dc:creator: Catrin Einhorn
item.media:credit: John Tully for The New York Times
item.media:description: A funnel for collecting urine in the home of Kate Lucy and Jon Sellers in Brattleboro, Vt.

item.title: A Better Way to Measure Immunity in Children
item.description: Some scientists believe that a clearer picture of Covid vaccine efficacy could have emerged sooner if investigators had tracked certain immune cells, not just antibodies.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.media:credit: William DeShazer for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jacqueline Almeida has experienced backlash from those who think she is too concerned about Covid. She is eager to get her young children vaccinated.

item.title: Ukraine Is Ruled Out of Staging Eurovision in 2023.
item.description: The Eurovision Song Contest’s organizers said on Friday that Russia’s invasion meant Ukraine could not stage next year’s event, even though it won this year’s contest.
item.dc:creator: Alex Marshall
item.media:credit: Alessandro Grassani for The New York Times
item.media:description: Kalush Orchestera last month at the Eurovision Song Contest in Turin, Italy.

item.title: Putin Denounces the U.S. as a Fading World Power
item.description: He also mocked what he called the country’s view of itself as “the messenger of the Lord on Earth.”
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski and Adam Satariano
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia at St. Petersburg International Economic Forum on Friday.

item.title: Dozens Injured by Hot Coals at Company Event in Zurich
item.description: More than two dozen employees of a Swiss company were injured while walking in bare feet over hot coals, an ancient religious tradition that has become popular on corporate retreats.
item.dc:creator: Alex Traub
item.media:description: People walking on burning coals as they take part in the ancient tradition of Anastenaria, a fire-walking ritual, in the northern Greek village of Mavrolefke, in 2019.

item.title: Relief for Parents
item.description: Covid vaccines for young children are finally coming.
item.dc:creator: German Lopez
item.media:credit: Emily Matthews/Pittsburgh Post-Gazette, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A 5-year-old girl receiving her first dose of a Pfizer Covid-19 vaccine in Pittsburgh this year.

item.title: Mariupol, a symbol of the war’s human cost, likely was Ukraine’s ‘deadliest place’ through April.
item.dc:creator: Rick Gladstone
item.media:description: While the vast majority of Mariupol’s residents fled the city, tens of thousands remained during a siege that lasted weeks. Thousands of residents are estimated to have died during the siege.

item.title: The European Commission recommends E.U. candidacy for Ukraine and Moldova, but not Georgia.
item.description: The Commission’s blessing is just the first step on a long road. The final decision will be in the hands of European Union leaders, who will meet June 23 and 24 in Brussels to tackle the thorny question.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff, Monika Pronczuk and Dan Bilefsky
item.media:description: Ursula von der Leyen, the president of the European Commission, arriving at E.U. headquarters in Brussels on Friday.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing
item.description: European leaders visit Kyiv.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Wolfe and Matthew Cullen
item.media:description: The leaders of Italy, Germany, France and Romania met with President Volodomyr Zelensky of Ukraine, center, in Kyiv on Thursday.

item.title: How a Globetrotting Family Learned to Love Soccer and the ‘Grey Wiggle’
item.description: Over many years and locations, we had come to almost worship the World Cup, something that let us bond with almost anyone, anywhere.
item.dc:creator: Damien Cave
item.media:description: Andrew Redmayne, right, Australia’s goalkeeper known as the “Grey Wiggle,” celebrated with teammates after it beat Peru and secured a spot in the World Cup later this year.

item.title: The U.S. announces a 3-year agriculture partnership with Ukraine to address the food crisis.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:credit: Finbarr O’Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: Before it was invaded by Russia, Ukraine ranked as the fourth-largest exporter of grain and seeds in the world.

item.title: Fears Grow Over Iran’s Nuclear Program as Tehran Digs a New Tunnel Network
item.description: The conflict over the program is about to flare again as President Biden travels next month to Israel and Saudi Arabia, Iran’s two biggest regional rivals.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger, Julian E. Barnes and Ronen Bergman
item.media:description: By most accounts, Iran is closer to being able to produce a bomb today than at any other point in the two-decade-long saga of its nuclear program.

item.title: France and Germany Stand With Ukraine, and Putin Can Wait
item.description: Seeking to overcome tensions with Kyiv, President Emmanuel Macron of France and Chancellor Olaf Scholz of Germany backed away from Moscow diplomacy, at least for now.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen
item.media:description: President Klaus Iohannis of Romania, Prime Minister Mario Draghi of Italy, President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine, President Emmanuel Macron of France and Chancellor Olaf Scholz of Germany holding a news conference after meeting in Kyiv, Ukraine, on Thursday.

item.title: Russia’s bank chief calls for economic ‘perestroika,’ away from raw exports.
item.dc:creator: Neil MacFarquhar
item.media:description: Elvira Nabiullina, governor of the Bank of Russia, at the St. Petersburg International Economic Forum in St. Petersburg, Russia, on Thursday.

item.title: Florida Didn’t Preorder Vaccine Doses for Youngest Children, State Says
item.description: It was not immediately clear how much the State Health Department’s decision not to take part in distributing the pediatric shots would impede access to them in Florida in the coming days.
item.dc:creator: Johnny Diaz and Noah Weiland
item.media:description: Children 5 to 11 years old receiving vaccine shots in November at an elementary school in Miami. Federal regulators are weighing authorization of pediatric vaccine doses for younger children.

item.title: Third American Fighter May Be Missing in Ukraine, State Department Says
item.description: A State Department spokesman did not provide specifics. Earlier reports that two U.S. veterans had been captured by Russian forces remain unconfirmed.
item.dc:creator: Anushka Patil
item.media:description: Ned Price, a U.S. State Department spokesperson, said a possible third American fighter had gone missing in Ukraine in recent weeks.

item.title: Europe Offers Ukraine a Hope of Joining the E.U., but Not a Vast Arsenal
item.description: In their first wartime visit to Kyiv, the leaders of France and Germany countered doubts about their commitment to Ukraine defeating Russia, but did not promise the weapons Ukrainians have called for.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer and Michael Levenson
item.media:description: The leaders of Italy, Germany, France and Romania met with President Volodomyr Zelensky of Ukraine in Kyiv on Thursday.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing: European Leaders Travel to Ukraine
item.description: Also, China rewrites Hong Kong’s history textbooks and a Trumpian candidate emerges in Colombia.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Cullen
item.media:description: From left: Italian Prime Minister Mario Draghi, German Chancellor Olaf Scholz, Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky, French President Emmanuel Macron and Romanian President Klaus Iohannis on Thursday.

item.title: Near Embattled Ukrainian Cities, a Mass Grave for Civilians Grows
item.description: As Russia solidifies control in Sievierodonetsk and shifts its focus to neighboring Lysychansk, civilian casualties there continue to mount.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Natalia Yermak
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier at a mass grave in the hills above the city of Lysychansk, in eastern Ukraine, on Thursday.

item.title: As European Leaders Visit Kyiv, Putin Cuts Their Gas Supply
item.description: At a critical moment in the war, Russia is strategically reducing gas flows to drive up prices and hurt European economies already reeling from high inflation.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold and Melissa Eddy
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron of France, Chancellor Olaf Scholz of Germany and Prime Minister Mario Draghi of Italy visiting Irpin, near Kyiv, Ukraine, on Thursday.

item.title: Federico Carboni Becomes Italy’s First Assisted Suicide
item.description: The man, Federico Carboni, overcame a series of legal and bureaucratic challenges before ending his life.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:description: On Thursday, Federico Carboni ended his life, becoming Italy’s first legal assisted suicide.

item.title: Union Strike in Tunisia Challenges President’s Rule
item.description: The union that called the strike has become the most powerful opponent of President Kais Saied as he tries to concentrate power.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.media:description: Trade unionists stage a rallied on Thursday during a strike called by the Tunisian General Labor Union in the capital, Tunis.

item.title: These Polar Bears in Greenland Can Survive With Less Sea Ice
item.description: The overall threat to the animals from climate change remains, but a new finding suggests that small numbers might survive for longer as the Arctic warms.
item.dc:creator: Henry Fountain

item.title: Little Amal, a Refugee Puppet Who Traveled Europe, Will Visit New York
item.description: Last year, the 12-foot-tall Syrian girl trekked from Turkey to Britain to find her mother. This fall, she’ll visit all five boroughs.
item.dc:creator: Julia Jacobs
item.media:credit: Elliott Verdier for The New York Times
item.media:description: Amal, followed by local children, in the coastal city of Calais, France, one of eight countries on last year’s journey.

item.title: Vaccination rates for the vulnerable are soaring in Africa, the W.H.O. says.
item.description: Encouraging news about Covid-19 vaccination rates among health workers and the elderly is tempered by warnings about the spread of monkeypox.
item.dc:creator: Declan Walsh
item.media:description: Ugandans received doses of the Pfizer-BioNTech coronavirus vaccine in February at the Kiswa Health Centre III in Kampala.

item.title: Moscow says babies born in occupied Kherson will automatically get Russian citizenship.
item.description: The move, part of an effort to integrate occupied Ukrainian areas with Russia, comes as Kyiv launches counterattacks to try to take back territories.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:description: Kherson, in Ukraine’s south, last month.

item.title: Civilians Are Largely Stranded in Sievierodonetsk, in One of the War’s Deadliest Battles
item.description: People in one city key city are now largely on their own. Those who have escaped describe harrowing scenes.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Marc Santora and Natalia Yermak
item.media:description: Lysychansk and Sievierodonetsk have seen sustained fighting between Russian and Ukrainian forces for weeks.

item.title: Mass Shootings Are a Reality in Many Communities
item.description: In some communities, shootings are a daily occurrence.
item.dc:creator: German Lopez
item.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jay Vaughn, in his Englewood neighborhood in Chicago.

item.title: Kevin Spacey, Accused of Sexual Assault, Appears in British Court
item.description: The proceedings are a rare example of a celebrity #MeToo case leading to criminal charges.
item.dc:creator: Alex Marshall
item.media:description: Kevin Spacey arriving on Thursday at Westminster Magistrates’ Court in London.

item.title: The leaders’ arrival draws a mixed reaction in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:description: Chancellor Olaf Scholz of Germany in the Kyiv suburb of Irpin on Thursday.

item.title: Macron says European leaders are bringing ‘a message of unity.’
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron of France arriving at the Kyiv train station on Thursday.

item.title: In New Textbooks, Hong Kong Was Never a British Colony
item.description: The books are part of China’s effort to instill a particular historical narrative and to stress patriotic education in a city where a pro-democracy movement was crushed.
item.dc:creator: Tiffany May
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: Students at Wong Tai Sin, in Hong Kong, last year. Bejing has launched a sweeping overhaul of the education system in the territory.

item.title: Draghi, Scholz and Macron face varying challenges on their Ukraine visit.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff, Katrin Bennhold and Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Destroyed apartment buildings in Irpin, Ukraine, on Wednesday.

item.title: A desperate flight to a better life at Lviv’s train station.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:credit: Emile Ducke for The New York Times
item.media:description: Iryna Ivanova, 35, and her daughters Svitlana, 11, and Diana, 4, boarded a train heading towards Uzhhorod, on the westernmost edge of Ukraine, from Lviv on Wednesday. The family originally evacuated from Pokrovsk, on the Donetsk regioin of eastern Ukraine.

item.title: European leaders assure Ukraine of support, but questions remain.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden, Matina Stevis-Gridneff, Katrin Bennhold and Anton Troianovski
item.media:description: The leaders of Italy, Germany, France and Romania met with President Volodomyr Zelensky of Ukraine in Kyiv on Thursday.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing
item.description: More military aid for Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soliders loading artillery in the Donetsk region last month.
